intro: Escobaria abdita, commonly known as the desert nightshade, is a succulent plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Solanaceae, which includes nightshades, and is characterized by its fleshy, cylindrical stems and small, star-shaped leaves. The plant produces bell-shaped flowers that are typically white or pale purple, which bloom in the evening. Escobaria abdita is adapted to arid environments, storing water in its thick stems and having a shallow root system to absorb moisture from the soil. It is often found in rocky or sandy soils and is a hardy species that thrives in full sun.
